summary.para: Gets or sets the font used for text (default: "Times-Roman"). This very much depends on the output format and, for non-bitmap output such as PostScript or SVG, the availability of the font when the graph is displayed or printed. As such, it is best to rely on font faces that are generally available, such as Times-Roman, Helvetica or Courier.

How font names are resolved also depends on the underlying library that handles font name resolution. If Graphviz was built using the fontconfig library, the latter library will be used to search for the font. See the commands fc-list, fc-match and the other fontconfig commands for how names are resolved and which fonts are available. Other systems may provide their own font package, such as Quartz for OS X.

Note that various font attributes, such as weight and slant, can be built into the font name. Unfortunately, the syntax varies depending on which font system is dominant. Thus, using = "times bold italic" will produce a bold, slanted Times font using Pango, the usual main font library. Alternatively, = "times:italic" will produce a slanted Times font from fontconfig, while = "times-bold" will resolve to a bold Times using Quartz. You will need to ascertain which package is used by your Graphviz system and refer to the relevant documentation.

If Graphviz is not built with a high-level font library, will be considered the name of a Type 1 or True Type font file. If you specify = "schlbk", the tool will look for a file named schlbk.ttf or schlbk.pfa or schlbk.pfb in one of the directories specified by the attribute of graph . The lookup does support various aliases for the common fonts.

summary.para: Gets or sets the color to use for the cluster (default: ).
If is specified, with no weighted colors in its parameters ( items only), and the fill style is used, a linear gradient fill is done.
If is used with weighted colors (see ), a degenerate linear gradient fill is done. This essentially does a fill using two colors, with the specifying how much of region is filled with each color.
If the fill style used is , then a radial gradient fill is done. See also the attribute of graph for setting a gradient angle globally, or its counterpart on individual clusters.
The fill style can also be set to do fills using more than 2 colors (set fill style to , and use as a color list definition).

Gets or sets the color used to fill the background of the cluster, assuming that the fill style is specified (default: ). If is not defined, is used. If is not defined, is used. If it is not defined too, the default is used, except when the output format is MIF, which use black by default.

When is used, a gradient fill is generated. By default, this is a linear fill; setting fill style to will cause a radial fill. If the second color is , the default color is used for it. See also the attribute on graph for setting a gradient angle globally, or its counterpart on individual clusters.
Note that a cluster inherits the root graph's attributes if defined. Thus, if the root graph has defined a , this will override a or set for the cluster.

member.summary: Specifies the width of the pen, in points, used to draw the bounding box around clusters. The value is inherited by subclusters. It has no effect on text. Default: 1.0, minimum: 0.0.

member.name: P:GiGraph.Dot.Entities.Attributes.Properties.Common.GraphCluster.IDotGraphClusterCommonAttributes.BorderColor
member.summary: A color used to draw the bounding box around the cluster (default: ). If is not defined, is used. If this is not defined, the default is used. Note that a cluster inherits the root graph's attributes if defined. Thus, if is defined globally for clusters, it will override a or attribute set for individual clusters.

summary.para: Hyperlinks incorporated into device-dependent output (svg, postscript, map only). At present, used in PS2, CMAP, I*MAP and SVG formats. For all these formats, URLs can be attached to nodes, edges and clusters. URL attributes can also be attached to the root graph in PS2, CMAP and I*MAP formats. This serves as the base URL for relative URLs in the former, and as the default image map file in the latter.
The active area for a cluster is its bounding box.

For SVG, CMAPX and IMAP output, the active area for a node is its visible image. For example, an unfilled node with no drawn boundary will only be active on its label. For other output, the active area is its bounding box.

For edges, the active areas are small circles where the edge contacts its head and tail nodes. In addition, for SVG, CMAPX and IMAP, the active area includes a thin polygon approximating the edge. The circles may overlap the related node, and the edge URL dominates. If the edge has a label, this will also be active. Finally, if the edge has a head or tail label, this will also be active.

Note that, for edges, the attribute of the head and the tail, the attribute of , and the attribute of , allow control of various parts of an edge. Also note that, if active areas of two edges overlap, it is unspecified which area dominates.

Multiple styles can be used at once, for example: = | ;

Gets or sets the label to display on the cluster. It may be plain text () or HTML ( ). See also for text justification and simple formatting and for custom text styling and defining tables. The latter one gives the most possibilities (specifying font, size, color, style, images, etc.).

member.name: P:GiGraph.Dot.Entities.Clusters.Attributes.IDotClusterAttributes.Tooltip
member.summary: Tooltip annotation attached to the cluster (svg, cmap only). If unset, Graphviz will use the attribute if defined.

summary.para: Gets or sets the background color of the cluster (default: none). Used as the initial background for the cluster. If the fill style is used for the cluster, its will overlay the background color.

When is used, a gradient fill is generated. By default, this is a linear fill; applying the fill style to the cluster will cause a radial fill. If the second color is , the default color is used for it. See also the attribute for setting a gradient angle.

member.name: P:GiGraph.Dot.Entities.Clusters.Attributes.IDotClusterAttributes.ColorScheme
member.summary: Specifies a color scheme namespace to use. If defined, specifies the context for interpreting color names. If no color scheme is set, the standard naming is used. For example, if Brewer color scheme is used, then a color named "7", e.g. Color.FromName("7"), will be evaluated in the context of that specific color scheme. See for supported scheme names.

member.name: P:GiGraph.Dot.Entities.Clusters.Attributes.IDotClusterAttributes.GradientFillAngle
member.summary: If a gradient fill is being used, this determines the angle of the fill. For linear fills, the colors transform along a line specified by the angle and the center of the object. For radial fills, a value of zero causes the colors to transform radially from the center; for non-zero values, the colors transform from a point near the object's periphery as specified by the value. If unset, the default angle is 0.

member.name: P:GiGraph.Dot.Entities.Clusters.Attributes.IDotClusterAttributes.Peripheries
member.summary: Sets the number of peripheries used in cluster boundaries (default: 1, minimum: 0, maximum: 1). Setting peripheries to 0 will remove the boundaries.

member.name: P:GiGraph.Dot.Entities.Clusters.Attributes.IDotClusterAttributes.Padding
member.summary: Specifies the space between the nodes in the cluster and bounding box of the cluster. By default, this is 8 points.

member.name: P:GiGraph.Dot.Entities.Clusters.Attributes.IDotClusterAttributes.SortIndex
member.summary: Gets or sets the sorting index of the cluster (default: 0). If indicates an array packing, this attribute specifies an insertion order among the components, with smaller values inserted first.

summary.para: Allows the graph author to provide an identifier for graph objects which is to be included in the output (svg, postscript, map only).
Normal , , substitutions can be applied (see ). Note, however, that does not provide a unique ID for multi-edges.

If provided, it is the responsibility of the provider to keep ID values unique for its intended downstream use. If no ID attribute is provided, then a unique internal ID is used. However, this value is unpredictable by the graph writer.

If the graph provides an ID attribute, this will be used as a prefix for internally generated attributes. By making internally-used attributes distinct, the user can include multiple image maps in the same document.

member.name: T:GiGraph.Dot.Entities.Clusters.DotCluster
member.summary: Represents a cluster subgraph. A cluster subgraph is a special type of subgraph whose appearance can be customized. If supported, the layout engine used to render it, will do the layout so that the nodes belonging to the cluster are drawn together, with the entire drawing of the cluster contained within a bounding rectangle. Note that cluster subgraphs are not part of the DOT language, but solely a syntactic convention adhered to by certain of the layout engines.

member.name: M:GiGraph.Dot.Entities.Clusters.DotCluster.#ctor(System.String)
member.summary: Creates a new cluster subgraph.
member.param: The unique identifier of the cluster.

summary.para: The subsections of the graph. They appear consecutively in the output DOT script, and inherit the graph attributes, and the global node and/or edge attributes of their predecessors. When overridden in any subsection, the new graph attributes and global node/edge attributes apply to the elements the section itself contains, and also to those that belong to the sections that follow it (if any).

Note that each subsection is dependent on the graph attributes and the global node and edge attributes specified by the sections that precede it (including those of the root section represented by the current element). Note also that some graph attributes cannot be overriden, and apply to the whole graph no matter in which section they are set.
As far as setting global node and/or edge attributes for a specific group of elements is concerned, may be the cleaner and preferable way to achieve the effect.

summary.para: Gets or sets the color to use for the cluster (default: ).
If is specified, with no weighted colors in its parameters ( items only), and the fill style is used, a linear gradient fill is done.
If is used with weighted colors (see ), a degenerate linear gradient fill is done. This essentially does a fill using two colors, with the specifying how much of region is filled with each color.
If the fill style used is , then a radial gradient fill is done. See also the attribute of graph for setting a gradient angle globally, or its counterpart on individual clusters.
The fill style can also be set to do fills using more than 2 colors (set fill style to , and use as a color list definition).

Gets or sets the color used to fill the background of the cluster, assuming that the fill style is specified (default: ). If is not defined, is used. If is not defined, is used. If it is not defined too, the default is used, except when the output format is MIF, which use black by default.

When is used, a gradient fill is generated. By default, this is a linear fill; setting fill style to will cause a radial fill. If the second color is , the default color is used for it. See also the attribute on graph for setting a gradient angle globally, or its counterpart on individual clusters.
Note that a cluster inherits the root graph's attributes if defined. Thus, if the root graph has defined a , this will override a or set for the cluster.

Note that a cluster inherits the root graph's attributes if defined. Thus, if is defined globally for clusters, it will override a or attribute set for individual clusters.

summary.para: Gets or sets the style of the cluster (default: unset). See the descriptions of individual values to learn which styles are applicable to this type of element.
Multiple styles can be used at once, for example: = | ;

Gets or sets the label to display on the cluster. It may be plain text () or HTML ( ). See also for text justification and simple formatting and for custom text styling and defining tables. The latter one gives the most possibilities (specifying font, size, color, style, images, etc.).

member.name: P:GiGraph.Dot.Entities.Clusters.DotClusterSection.Tooltip
member.summary: Tooltip annotation attached to the cluster (svg, cmap only). If unset, Graphviz will use the attribute if defined.

summary.para: Gets or sets the background color of the cluster (default: none). Used as the initial background for the cluster. If the fill style is used for the cluster, its will overlay the background color.

When is used, a gradient fill is generated. By default, this is a linear fill; applying the fill style to the cluster will cause a radial fill. If the second color is , the default color is used for it. See also the attribute for setting a gradient angle.

member.name: P:GiGraph.Dot.Entities.Clusters.DotClusterSection.ColorScheme
member.summary: Specifies a color scheme namespace to use. If defined, specifies the context for interpreting color names. If no color scheme is set, the standard naming is used. For example, if Brewer color scheme is used, then a color named "7", e.g. Color.FromName("7"), will be evaluated in the context of that specific color scheme. See for supported scheme names.

member.name: P:GiGraph.Dot.Entities.Clusters.DotClusterSection.GradientFillAngle
member.summary: If a gradient fill is being used, this determines the angle of the fill. For linear fills, the colors transform along a line specified by the angle and the center of the object. For radial fills, a value of zero causes the colors to transform radially from the center; for non-zero values, the colors transform from a point near the object's periphery as specified by the value. If unset, the default angle is 0.

member.name: P:GiGraph.Dot.Entities.Clusters.DotClusterSection.Peripheries
member.summary: Sets the number of peripheries used in cluster boundaries (default: 1, minimum: 0, maximum: 1). Setting peripheries to 0 will remove the boundaries.

member.name: P:GiGraph.Dot.Entities.Clusters.DotClusterSection.Padding
member.summary: Specifies the space between the nodes in the cluster and bounding box of the cluster. By default, this is 8 points.

member.name: P:GiGraph.Dot.Entities.Clusters.DotClusterSection.SortIndex
member.summary: Gets or sets the sorting index of the cluster (default: 0). If indicates an array packing, this attribute specifies an insertion order among the components, with smaller values inserted first.

summary.para: Allows the graph author to provide an identifier for graph objects which is to be included in the output (svg, postscript, map only).
Normal , , substitutions can be applied (see ). Note, however, that does not provide a unique ID for multi-edges.

If provided, it is the responsibility of the provider to keep ID values unique for its intended downstream use. If no ID attribute is provided, then a unique internal ID is used. However, this value is unpredictable by the graph writer.

If the graph provides an ID attribute, this will be used as a prefix for internally generated attributes. By making internally-used attributes distinct, the user can include multiple image maps in the same document.

member.summary: Multiplicative scaling factor adjusting the distance that the the head and tail labels are from the head/tail nodes (see on the head and the tail of the edge). The default distance is 10 points, the minimum is 0.0. See also .

summary.para: This, along with , determine where the the head and tail labels are placed with respect to the head/tail in polar coordinates (see on the head and on the tail of the edge). The origin in the coordinate system is the point where the edge touches the node. The ray of 0 degrees goes from the origin back along the edge, parallel to the edge at the origin.

The angle, in degrees, specifies the rotation from the 0 degree ray, with positive angles moving counterclockwise and negative angles moving clockwise. The default value is -25.0, the minimum: -180.0.

summary.para: Gets or sets the style of the edge (default: unset). See the descriptions of individual values to learn which styles are applicable to this type of element.
Multiple styles can be used at once, for example: = | ;

Gets or sets the label to display next to the edge. It may be plain text () or HTML ( ). See also for text justification and simple formatting and for custom text styling and defining tables. The latter one gives the most possibilities (specifying font, size, color, style, images, etc.).

External label for the edge. The label will be placed near the center of the edge. This can be useful in dot to avoid the occasional problem when the use of edge labels distorts the layout. For other layouts, this attribute can be viewed as a synonym for the attribute.

These labels are added after all nodes and edges have been placed. The labels will be placed so that they do not overlap any node or label. This means it may not be possible to place all of them. To force placing all of them, use the attribute on the graph.

member.name: P:GiGraph.Dot.Entities.Edges.Attributes.IDotEdgeAttributes.AllowLabelFloat
member.summary: If true, allows edge labels to be less constrained in position. In particular, it may appear on top of other edges. Default: false.

member.name: P:GiGraph.Dot.Entities.Edges.Attributes.IDotEdgeAttributes.MinLength
member.summary: Minimum edge length (rank difference between head and tail). Dot only, default: 1, minimum: 0.

member.name: P:GiGraph.Dot.Entities.Edges.Attributes.IDotEdgeAttributes.Length
member.summary: Preferred edge length, in inches (fdp, neato only). Default: 1.0 (neato), 0.3 (fdp).

member.name: P:GiGraph.Dot.Entities.Edges.Attributes.IDotEdgeAttributes.Weight
member.summary: Weight of the edge. In dot, the heavier the weight, the shorter, straighter and more vertical the edge is. Note that weights in dot must be integers. For twopi, a weight of 0 indicates the edge should not be used in constructing a spanning tree from the root. For other layouts, a larger weight encourages the layout to make the edge length closer to that specified by the attribute. Default: 1. Minimum: 0 [int] (dot, twopi), 1 [double] (neato, fdp).

member.name: P:GiGraph.Dot.Entities.Edges.Attributes.IDotEdgeAttributes.Tooltip
member.summary: Tooltip annotation attached to the edge (svg, cmap only). If unset, Graphviz will use the attribute if defined.

summary.para: Gets or sets the color to use for the edge (default: ).

If is used, with no weighted colors in its color collection ( items only), the edge is drawn using parallel splines or lines, one for each color in the list, in the order given. The head arrow, if any, is drawn using the first color in the list, and the tail arrow, if any, the second color. This supports the common case of drawing opposing edges, but using parallel splines instead of separately routed multiedges.
If is used with at least one weighted color (), the colors are drawn in series, with each color being given roughly its specified fraction of the edge, expressed by the property.

member.name: P:GiGraph.Dot.Entities.Edges.Attributes.IDotEdgeAttributes.FillColor
member.summary: Gets or sets the color used to fill the arrowhead, assuming it has a filled style. If is not defined, is used. If it is not defined too, the default is used, except when the output format is MIF, which use black by default.

member.name: P:GiGraph.Dot.Entities.Edges.Attributes.IDotEdgeAttributes.ColorScheme
member.summary: Specifies a color scheme namespace to use. If defined, specifies the context for interpreting color names. If no color scheme is set, the standard naming is used. For example, if Brewer color scheme is used, then a color named "7", e.g. Color.FromName("7"), will be evaluated in the context of that specific color scheme. See for supported scheme names.

member.name: P:GiGraph.Dot.Entities.Edges.Attributes.IDotEdgeAttributes.Width
member.summary: Specifies the width of the pen, in points, used to draw lines and curves, including the boundaries of edges. The value has no effect on text. Default: 1.0, minimum: 0.0.

member.name: P:GiGraph.Dot.Entities.Edges.Attributes.IDotEdgeAttributes.ArrowheadScale
member.summary: Gets or sets the multiplicative scale factor for arrowheads (default: 1.0, minimum: 0.0).

summary.para: Gets or sets edge type for drawing arrowheads. Default: (for directed graphs), (for undirected graphs).
Indicates which ends of the edge should be decorated with an arrowhead. The actual style of the arrowhead may be specified using the attribute on the head or tail of the edge.
A glyph is drawn at the head end of the edge if and only if the direction is or .
A glyph is drawn at the tail end of the edge if and only if the direction is or .
For undirected edges T -- H, one of the nodes, usually the right hand one, is treated as the head for the purpose of interpreting and .

member.name: P:GiGraph.Dot.Entities.Edges.Attributes.IDotEdgeAttributes.AttachLabel
member.summary: If true, attaches label to the edge by a 2-segment polyline, underlining the label, then going to the closest point of spline. Default: false.

summary.para: Allows the graph author to provide an identifier for graph objects which is to be included in the output (svg, postscript, map only).
Normal , , substitutions can be applied (see ). Note, however, that does not provide a unique ID for multi-edges.

If provided, it is the responsibility of the provider to keep ID values unique for its intended downstream use. If no ID attribute is provided, then a unique internal ID is used. However, this value is unpredictable by the graph writer.

If the graph provides an ID attribute, this will be used as a prefix for internally generated attributes. By making internally-used attributes distinct, the user can include multiple image maps in the same document.

summary.para: Allows the graph author to provide an identifier for graph objects which is to be included in the output (svg, postscript, map only).
Normal , , substitutions can be applied (see ). Note, however, that does not provide a unique ID for multi-edges.

If provided, it is the responsibility of the provider to keep ID values unique for its intended downstream use. If no ID attribute is provided, then a unique internal ID is used. However, this value is unpredictable by the graph writer.

If the graph provides an ID attribute, this will be used as a prefix for internally generated attributes. By making internally-used attributes distinct, the user can include multiple image maps in the same document.

summary.para: Gets or sets the label to display next to the edge. It may be plain text () or HTML ( ). See also for text justification and simple formatting and for custom text styling and defining tables. The latter one gives the most possibilities (specifying font, size, color, style, images, etc.).

External label for the edge. The label will be placed near the center of the edge. This can be useful in dot to avoid the occasional problem when the use of edge labels distorts the layout. For other layouts, this attribute can be viewed as a synonym for the attribute.

These labels are added after all nodes and edges have been placed. The labels will be placed so that they do not overlap any node or label. This means it may not be possible to place all of them. To force placing all of them, use the attribute on the graph.

member.name: P:GiGraph.Dot.Entities.Edges.DotEdgeDefinition.AllowLabelFloat
member.summary: If true, allows edge labels to be less constrained in position. In particular, it may appear on top of other edges. Default: false.

member.name: P:GiGraph.Dot.Entities.Edges.DotEdgeDefinition.MinLength
member.summary: Minimum edge length (rank difference between head and tail). Dot only, default: 1, minimum: 0.

member.name: P:GiGraph.Dot.Entities.Edges.DotEdgeDefinition.Length
member.summary: Preferred edge length, in inches (fdp, neato only). Default: 1.0 (neato), 0.3 (fdp).

member.name: P:GiGraph.Dot.Entities.Edges.DotEdgeDefinition.Weight
member.summary: Weight of the edge. In dot, the heavier the weight, the shorter, straighter and more vertical the edge is. Note that weights in dot must be integers. For twopi, a weight of 0 indicates the edge should not be used in constructing a spanning tree from the root. For other layouts, a larger weight encourages the layout to make the edge length closer to that specified by the attribute. Default: 1. Minimum: 0 [int] (dot, twopi), 1 [double] (neato, fdp).

member.name: P:GiGraph.Dot.Entities.Edges.DotEdgeDefinition.Tooltip
member.summary: Tooltip annotation attached to the edge (svg, cmap only). If unset, Graphviz will use the attribute if defined.

summary.para: Gets or sets the color to use for the edge (default: ).

If is used, with no weighted colors in its color collection ( items only), the edge is drawn using parallel splines or lines, one for each color in the list, in the order given. The head arrow, if any, is drawn using the first color in the list, and the tail arrow, if any, the second color. This supports the common case of drawing opposing edges, but using parallel splines instead of separately routed multiedges.
If is used with at least one weighted color (), the colors are drawn in series, with each color being given roughly its specified fraction of the edge, expressed by the property.

member.name: P:GiGraph.Dot.Entities.Edges.DotEdgeDefinition.FillColor
member.summary: Gets or sets the color used to fill the arrowhead, assuming it has a filled style. If is not defined, is used. If it is not defined too, the default is used, except when the output format is MIF, which use black by default.

member.name: P:GiGraph.Dot.Entities.Edges.DotEdgeDefinition.ColorScheme
member.summary: Specifies a color scheme namespace to use. If defined, specifies the context for interpreting color names. If no color scheme is set, the standard naming is used. For example, if Brewer color scheme is used, then a color named "7", e.g. Color.FromName("7"), will be evaluated in the context of that specific color scheme. See for supported scheme names.

member.name: P:GiGraph.Dot.Entities.Edges.DotEdgeDefinition.Width
member.summary: Specifies the width of the pen, in points, used to draw lines and curves, including the boundaries of edges. The value has no effect on text. Default: 1.0, minimum: 0.0.

member.name: P:GiGraph.Dot.Entities.Edges.DotEdgeDefinition.ArrowheadScale
member.summary: Gets or sets the multiplicative scale factor for arrowheads (default: 1.0, minimum: 0.0).

summary.para: Gets or sets edge type for drawing arrowheads. Default: (for directed graphs), (for undirected graphs).
Indicates which ends of the edge should be decorated with an arrowhead. The actual style of the arrowhead may be specified using the attribute on the head or tail of the edge.
A glyph is drawn at the head end of the edge if and only if the direction is or .
A glyph is drawn at the tail end of the edge if and only if the direction is or .
For undirected edges T -- H, one of the nodes, usually the right hand one, is treated as the head for the purpose of interpreting and .

summary.para: Gets or sets the style of arrowhead at the end of the edge (default: ). Appears only if the attribute on the edge is (when specifying an arrowhead for the head endpoint), (when specifying an arrowhead for the tail endpoint), or .

For basic shapes, assign a value of the enumeration to this property (it will be converted implicitly). For variants of the basic shapes (filled/empty, normal/clipped) use . To generate an arrow composed of multiple arrowheads use .

summary.para: Gets or sets the background color of the graph (default: none). Used as the background for entire canvas.

When is used, a gradient fill is generated. By default, this is a linear fill; applying the fill style to the graph will cause a radial fill. If the second color is , the default color is used for it. See also the attribute for setting a gradient angle.

For certain output formats, such as PostScript, no fill is done for the root graph unless background color is explicitly set. For bitmap formats, however, the bits need to be initialized to something, so the canvas is filled with white by default. This means that if the bitmap output is included in some other document, all of the bits within the bitmap bounding box will be set, overwriting whatever color or graphics were already on the page. If this effect is not desired, and you only want to set bits explicitly assigned in drawing the graph, set = .

member.name: P:GiGraph.Dot.Entities.Graphs.Attributes.DotGraphCanvasAttributes.GradientFillAngle
member.summary: If a gradient fill is being used, this determines the angle of the fill. For linear fills, the colors transform along a line specified by the angle and the center of the object. For radial fills, a value of zero causes the colors to transform radially from the center; for non-zero values, the colors transform from a point near the object's periphery as specified by the value. If unset, the default angle is 0.

member.name: P:GiGraph.Dot.Entities.Graphs.Attributes.DotGraphCanvasAttributes.CenterDrawing
member.summary: If true, the drawing is centered in the output canvas (default: false).

member.name: P:GiGraph.Dot.Entities.Graphs.Attributes.DotGraphCanvasAttributes.Orientation
member.summary: Sets graph orientation to landscape or portrait (default). Used only if is not defined. See also .

member.name: P:GiGraph.Dot.Entities.Graphs.Attributes.DotGraphCanvasAttributes.OrientationAngle
member.summary: If 90, sets drawing orientation to landscape (default: 0). See also and .

member.name: P:GiGraph.Dot.Entities.Graphs.Attributes.DotGraphCanvasAttributes.LandscapeOrientation
member.summary: If true, the graph is rendered in landscape mode (default: false). Synonymous with = 90 or = .

member.name: P:GiGraph.Dot.Entities.Graphs.Attributes.DotGraphCanvasAttributes.Dpi
member.summary: Specifies the expected number of pixels per inch on a display device (svg, bitmap output only; default: 96.0, 0.0). For bitmap output, this guarantees that text rendering will be done more accurately, both in size and in placement. For SVG output, it is used to guarantee that the dimensions in the output correspond to the correct number of points or inches.

member.name: P:GiGraph.Dot.Entities.Graphs.Attributes.DotGraphCanvasAttributes.Resolution
member.summary: This is a synonym for the attribute (svg, bitmap output only; default: 96.0, 0.0).

summary.para: The maximum width and height of drawing, in inches. If only a single number is given, this is used for both the width and the height.
If defined and the drawing is larger than the given size, the drawing is uniformly scaled down so that it fits within the given size.

If is set, then the size specified is taken to be the desired size. In this case, if both dimensions of the drawing are less than size, the drawing is scaled up uniformly until at least one dimension equals its dimension in size.
Note that there is some interaction between the and the attributes.
Gets or sets the clipping window on final drawing. Supersedes any attribute. The width and height of the viewport specify precisely the final size of the output.

To specify width, height, and zoom of the final drawing, use . To also specify a central point of the drawing, use , or, to specify a node as a central point, use . By default, the focus is the center of the graph bounding box, i.e., (bbx / 2, bby / 2), where "bbx, bby" is the value of the bounding box attribute bb.

Gets or sets the aspect ratio (drawing height / drawing width) for the drawing. Note that this is adjusted before the attribute constraints are enforced. In addition, the calculations usually ignore the node sizes, so the final drawing size may only approximate what is desired.

If ratio is numeric (), it is taken as the desired aspect ratio. Then, if the actual aspect ratio is less than the desired ratio, the drawing height is scaled up to achieve the desired ratio; if the actual ratio is greater than that desired ratio, the drawing width is scaled up.
See also for non-numeric options of the ratio.
Sets x and y margins of canvas, in inches (default: device-dependent). If the margin is a single double, both margins are set equal to the given value.

Note that the margin is not part of the drawing but just empty space left around the drawing. It basically corresponds to a translation of drawing, as would be necessary to center a drawing on a page. Nothing is actually drawn in the margin. To actually extend the background of a drawing, see the attribute.

Specifies how much, in inches, to extend the drawing area around the minimal area needed to draw the graph. This area is part of the drawing, and will be filled with the background color, if appropriate. Default: 0.0555 (4 points).
Normally, a small pad is used for aesthetic reasons, especially when a background color is used, to avoid having nodes and edges abutting the boundary of the drawn region.

member.name: P:GiGraph.Dot.Entities.Graphs.Attributes.DotGraphLayoutAttributes.Rotation
member.summary: Rotates the final layout counter-clockwise by the specified number of degrees (sfdp only; default: 0).

member.name: P:GiGraph.Dot.Entities.Graphs.Attributes.DotGraphLayoutAttributes.RepeatCrossingMinimization
member.summary: If true and there are multiple clusters, runs crossing minimization a second time (dot only, default: true).

summary.para: Determines whether to use a single global ranking, ignoring clusters (dot only, default: false).

The original ranking algorithm in dot is recursive on clusters. This can produce fewer ranks and a more compact layout, but sometimes at the cost of a head node being placed on a higher rank than the tail node. It also assumes that a node is not constrained in separate, incompatible subgraphs. For example, a node cannot be in a cluster and also be constrained by a rank of with a node not in the cluster (see on subgraph attributes).
This allows nodes to be subject to multiple constraints. Rank constraints will usually take precedence over edge constraints. See also .

member.name: P:GiGraph.Dot.Entities.Graphs.Attributes.DotGraphLayoutAttributes.NodeRank
member.summary: Gets or sets the rank constraints on the nodes in the graph (dot only). See also .

summary.para: If enabled (see ), each connected component of the graph is laid out separately, and then the graphs are packed together.

If an integral value is specified (see ), this is used as the size, in
points
, of a margin around each part; otherwise, a default margin of 8 is used.
If disabled (see ), the entire graph is laid out together. The granularity and method of packing is influenced by the attribute.
Default: disabled (see ).

member.name: P:GiGraph.Dot.Entities.Graphs.Attributes.DotGraphLayoutAttributes.PackingMode
member.summary: Indicates how connected components should be packed (default: ). Note that specifying a value for this property will automatically turn on packing as though one had set = true.

summary.para: In dot, this specifies the minimum space between two adjacent nodes in the same rank, in inches (default: 0.25, minimum: 0.02).
For other layouts, this affects the spacing between loops on a single node, or multiedges between a pair of nodes.

In dot, this gives the desired rank separation, in inches (; default: 0.5, minimum: 0.02. This is the minimum vertical distance between the bottom of the nodes in one rank and the tops of nodes in the next.

In twopi, this attribute specifies the radial separation of concentric circles (default: 1, minimum: 0.02). For twopi, this can also be a list of doubles (). The first double specifies the radius of the inner circle; the second double specifies the increase in radius from the first circle to the second; etc. If there are more circles than numbers, the last number is used as the increment for the remainder.
Twopi, dot only.

member.name: P:GiGraph.Dot.Entities.Graphs.Attributes.DotGraphLayoutAttributes.ConcentrateEdges
member.summary: If true, edge concentrators are used (default: false). This merges multiedges into a single edge, and causes partially parallel edges to share part of their paths. The latter feature is not yet available outside of dot.

summary.para: Specifies the name of the layout algorithm to use, such as dot or neato (see for a list of available layout engines).

Normally, graphs should be kept independent of a type of layout. In some cases, however, it can be convenient to embed the type of layout desired within the graph. For example, a graph containing position information from a layout might want to record what the associated layout algorithm was. This attribute takes precedence over the -K flag or the actual command name used.

member.name: P:GiGraph.Dot.Entities.Graphs.Attributes.DotGraphLayoutAttributes.Direction
member.summary: Gets or sets the direction of graph layout (dot only, default: ).

member.name: P:GiGraph.Dot.Entities.Graphs.Attributes.DotGraphLayoutAttributes.EdgeOrderingMode
member.summary: Determines how inedges and outedges, that is, edges with a node as their head or tail node respectively, are ordered (dot only). If defined on a graph or subgraph, the value is applied to all nodes in the graph or subgraph. Note that the graph attribute takes precedence over a corresponding attribute on nodes.

member.name: P:GiGraph.Dot.Entities.Graphs.Attributes.DotGraphLayoutAttributes.ForceExternalLabels
member.summary: If true, all node and edge attributes are placed, even if there is some overlap with nodes or other labels (default: true).

member.name: P:GiGraph.Dot.Entities.Graphs.Attributes.DotGraphLayoutAttributes.SortIndex
member.summary: Gets or sets the sorting index of the graph (default: 0). If indicates an array packing, this attribute specifies an insertion order among the components, with smaller values inserted first.

summary.para: Gets or sets the label to display on the graph. It may be plain text () or HTML ( ). See also for text justification and simple formatting and for custom text styling and defining tables. The latter one gives the most possibilities (specifying font, size, color, style, images, etc.).

member.name: P:GiGraph.Dot.Entities.Graphs.Attributes.IDotGraphAttributes.ColorScheme
member.summary: Specifies a color scheme namespace to use. If defined, specifies the context for interpreting color names. If no color scheme is set, the standard naming is used. For example, if Brewer color scheme is used, then a color named "7", e.g. Color.FromName("7"), will be evaluated in the context of that specific color scheme. See for supported scheme names.

member.name: P:GiGraph.Dot.Entities.Graphs.Attributes.IDotGraphAttributes.Charset
member.summary: Specifies the character encoding used when interpreting string input as a text label. The default value is "UTF-8". The other legal value is "iso-8859-1" or, equivalently, "Latin1". The charset attribute is case-insensitive. Note that if the character encoding used in the input does not match the charset value, the resulting output may be very strange.

member.name: P:GiGraph.Dot.Entities.Graphs.Attributes.IDotGraphAttributes.Comment
member.summary: Comments are inserted into output. Device-dependent.

summary.para: Specifies a list of directories in which to look for image files used by nodes, referenced either by the of their attributes, or from the IMG element in HTML-like labels. The string should be a list of (absolute or relative) path names, each separated by a semicolon (for Windows) or a colon (all other OS). The first directory in which a file of the given name is found will be used to load the image.
If not set, relative path names for image files will be interpreted with respect to the current working directory.
The identifier of a node that should be used as the center of the layout and the root of the generated spanning tree (circo, twopi only).

In twopi, root will actually be the central node. In circo, the block containing the node will be central in the drawing of its connected component. If not defined, twopi will pick a most central node, and circo will pick a random node.
If the attribute is defined as the empty string, twopi will reset it to name of the node picked as the root node.
For twopi, it is possible to have multiple roots, presumably one for each component. If more than one node in a component is marked as the root, twopi will pick one (see the attribute on a node).
Allows the graph author to provide an identifier for graph objects which is to be included in the output (svg, postscript, map only).
Normal , , substitutions can be applied (see ). Note, however, that does not provide a unique ID for multi-edges.

If provided, it is the responsibility of the provider to keep ID values unique for its intended downstream use. If no ID attribute is provided, then a unique internal ID is used. However, this value is unpredictable by the graph writer.

If the graph provides an ID attribute, this will be used as a prefix for internally generated attributes. By making internally-used attributes distinct, the user can include multiple image maps in the same document.
Gets or sets the background color of the graph (default: none). Used as the background for entire canvas.

When is used, a gradient fill is generated. By default, this is a linear fill; applying the fill style to the graph will cause a radial fill. If the second color is , the default color is used for it. See also the attribute for setting a gradient angle.

For certain output formats, such as PostScript, no fill is done for the root graph unless background color is explicitly set. For bitmap formats, however, the bits need to be initialized to something, so the canvas is filled with white by default. This means that if the bitmap output is included in some other document, all of the bits within the bitmap bounding box will be set, overwriting whatever color or graphics were already on the page. If this effect is not desired, and you only want to set bits explicitly assigned in drawing the graph, set = .

member.name: P:GiGraph.Dot.Entities.Graphs.Attributes.IDotGraphCanvasAttributes.GradientFillAngle
member.summary: If a gradient fill is being used, this determines the angle of the fill. For linear fills, the colors transform along a line specified by the angle and the center of the object. For radial fills, a value of zero causes the colors to transform radially from the center; for non-zero values, the colors transform from a point near the object's periphery as specified by the value. If unset, the default angle is 0.

member.name: P:GiGraph.Dot.Entities.Graphs.Attributes.IDotGraphCanvasAttributes.CenterDrawing
member.summary: If true, the drawing is centered in the output canvas (default: false).

member.name: P:GiGraph.Dot.Entities.Graphs.Attributes.IDotGraphCanvasAttributes.Orientation
member.summary: Sets graph orientation to landscape or portrait (default). Used only if is not defined. See also .

member.name: P:GiGraph.Dot.Entities.Graphs.Attributes.IDotGraphCanvasAttributes.OrientationAngle
member.summary: If 90, sets drawing orientation to landscape (default: 0). See also and .

member.name: P:GiGraph.Dot.Entities.Graphs.Attributes.IDotGraphCanvasAttributes.LandscapeOrientation
member.summary: If true, the graph is rendered in landscape mode (default: false). Synonymous with = 90 or = .

member.name: P:GiGraph.Dot.Entities.Graphs.Attributes.IDotGraphCanvasAttributes.Dpi
member.summary: Specifies the expected number of pixels per inch on a display device (svg, bitmap output only; default: 96.0, 0.0). For bitmap output, this guarantees that text rendering will be done more accurately, both in size and in placement. For SVG output, it is used to guarantee that the dimensions in the output correspond to the correct number of points or inches.

member.name: P:GiGraph.Dot.Entities.Graphs.Attributes.IDotGraphCanvasAttributes.Resolution
member.summary: This is a synonym for the attribute (svg, bitmap output only; default: 96.0, 0.0).

summary.para: The maximum width and height of drawing, in inches. If only a single number is given, this is used for both the width and the height.
If defined and the drawing is larger than the given size, the drawing is uniformly scaled down so that it fits within the given size.

If is set, then the size specified is taken to be the desired size. In this case, if both dimensions of the drawing are less than size, the drawing is scaled up uniformly until at least one dimension equals its dimension in size.
Note that there is some interaction between the and the attributes.

Specifies how much, in inches, to extend the drawing area around the minimal area needed to draw the graph. This area is part of the drawing, and will be filled with the background color, if appropriate. Default: 0.0555 (4 points).
Normally, a small pad is used for aesthetic reasons, especially when a background color is used, to avoid having nodes and edges abutting the boundary of the drawn region.
Sets x and y margins of canvas, in inches (default: device-dependent). If the margin is a single double, both margins are set equal to the given value.

Note that the margin is not part of the drawing but just empty space left around the drawing. It basically corresponds to a translation of drawing, as would be necessary to center a drawing on a page. Nothing is actually drawn in the margin. To actually extend the background of a drawing, see the attribute.

Gets or sets the aspect ratio (drawing height / drawing width) for the drawing. Note that this is adjusted before the attribute constraints are enforced. In addition, the calculations usually ignore the node sizes, so the final drawing size may only approximate what is desired.

If ratio is numeric (), it is taken as the desired aspect ratio. Then, if the actual aspect ratio is less than the desired ratio, the drawing height is scaled up to achieve the desired ratio; if the actual ratio is greater than that desired ratio, the drawing width is scaled up.
See also for non-numeric options of the ratio.
Gets or sets the clipping window on final drawing. Supersedes any attribute. The width and height of the viewport specify precisely the final size of the output.

To specify width, height, and zoom of the final drawing, use . To also specify a central point of the drawing, use , or, to specify a node as a central point, use . By default, the focus is the center of the graph bounding box, i.e., (bbx / 2, bby / 2), where "bbx, bby" is the value of the bounding box attribute bb.

member.name: P:GiGraph.Dot.Entities.Graphs.Attributes.IDotGraphClustersAttributes.AllowEdgeClipping
member.summary: If true, allows edges between clusters (dot only, default: false). Specify a for an edge's head or tail to attach it to the border of the cluster with that identifier.

member.name: P:GiGraph.Dot.Entities.Graphs.Attributes.IDotGraphClustersAttributes.VisualizationMode
member.summary: Mode used for handling clusters (dot only; default: ).

member.name: P:GiGraph.Dot.Entities.Graphs.Attributes.IDotGraphClustersRootAttributes.Style
member.summary: Style options. Note that the options are shared with those of the graph.

member.name: P:GiGraph.Dot.Entities.Graphs.Attributes.IDotGraphFontAttributes.Directories
member.summary: Gets or sets the directory list used by libgd to search for bitmap fonts if Graphviz was not built with the fontconfig library. If is not set, the environment variable DOTFONTPATH is checked. If that is not set, GDFONTPATH is checked. If not set, libgd uses its compiled-in font path. The default path is system dependent.

member.name: P:GiGraph.Dot.Entities.Graphs.Attributes.IDotGraphFontAttributes.Convention
member.summary: Allows user control of how basic font names are represented in SVG output (svg only; default: ).

summary.para: Specifies the name of the layout algorithm to use, such as dot or neato (see for a list of available layout engines).

Normally, graphs should be kept independent of a type of layout. In some cases, however, it can be convenient to embed the type of layout desired within the graph. For example, a graph containing position information from a layout might want to record what the associated layout algorithm was. This attribute takes precedence over the -K flag or the actual command name used.

member.name: P:GiGraph.Dot.Entities.Graphs.Attributes.IDotGraphLayoutAttributes.Direction
member.summary: Gets or sets the direction of graph layout (dot only, default: ).

member.name: P:GiGraph.Dot.Entities.Graphs.Attributes.IDotGraphLayoutAttributes.EdgeOrderingMode
member.summary: Determines how inedges and outedges, that is, edges with a node as their head or tail node respectively, are ordered (dot only). If defined on a graph or subgraph, the value is applied to all nodes in the graph or subgraph. Note that the graph attribute takes precedence over a corresponding attribute on nodes.

member.name: P:GiGraph.Dot.Entities.Graphs.Attributes.IDotGraphLayoutAttributes.ForceExternalLabels
member.summary: If true, all node and edge attributes are placed, even if there is some overlap with nodes or other labels (default: true).

member.name: P:GiGraph.Dot.Entities.Graphs.Attributes.IDotGraphLayoutAttributes.Rotation
member.summary: Rotates the final layout counter-clockwise by the specified number of degrees (sfdp only; default: 0).

member.name: P:GiGraph.Dot.Entities.Graphs.Attributes.IDotGraphLayoutAttributes.ConcentrateEdges
member.summary: If true, edge concentrators are used (default: false). This merges multiedges into a single edge, and causes partially parallel edges to share part of their paths. The latter feature is not yet available outside of dot.

summary.para: In dot, this specifies the minimum space between two adjacent nodes in the same rank, in inches (default: 0.25, minimum: 0.02).
For other layouts, this affects the spacing between loops on a single node, or multiedges between a pair of nodes.

member.name: P:GiGraph.Dot.Entities.Graphs.Attributes.IDotGraphLayoutAttributes.NodeRank
member.summary: Gets or sets the rank constraints on the nodes in the graph (dot only). See also .

summary.para: In dot, this gives the desired rank separation, in inches (; default: 0.5, minimum: 0.02. This is the minimum vertical distance between the bottom of the nodes in one rank and the tops of nodes in the next.

In twopi, this attribute specifies the radial separation of concentric circles (default: 1, minimum: 0.02). For twopi, this can also be a list of doubles (). The first double specifies the radius of the inner circle; the second double specifies the increase in radius from the first circle to the second; etc. If there are more circles than numbers, the last number is used as the increment for the remainder.
Twopi, dot only.
If enabled (see ), each connected component of the graph is laid out separately, and then the graphs are packed together.

If an integral value is specified (see ), this is used as the size, in
points
, of a margin around each part; otherwise, a default margin of 8 is used.
If disabled (see ), the entire graph is laid out together. The granularity and method of packing is influenced by the attribute.
Default: disabled (see ).

member.name: P:GiGraph.Dot.Entities.Graphs.Attributes.IDotGraphLayoutAttributes.PackingMode
member.summary: Indicates how connected components should be packed (default: ). Note that specifying a value for this property will automatically turn on packing as though one had set = true.

member.name: P:GiGraph.Dot.Entities.Graphs.Attributes.IDotGraphLayoutAttributes.RepeatCrossingMinimization
member.summary: If true and there are multiple clusters, runs crossing minimization a second time (dot only, default: true).

summary.para: Determines whether to use a single global ranking, ignoring clusters (dot only, default: false).

The original ranking algorithm in dot is recursive on clusters. This can produce fewer ranks and a more compact layout, but sometimes at the cost of a head node being placed on a higher rank than the tail node. It also assumes that a node is not constrained in separate, incompatible subgraphs. For example, a node cannot be in a cluster and also be constrained by a rank of with a node not in the cluster (see on subgraph attributes).
This allows nodes to be subject to multiple constraints. Rank constraints will usually take precedence over edge constraints. See also .

member.name: P:GiGraph.Dot.Entities.Graphs.Attributes.IDotGraphLayoutAttributes.SortIndex
member.summary: Gets or sets the sorting index of the graph (default: 0). If indicates an array packing, this attribute specifies an insertion order among the components, with smaller values inserted first.

summary.para: Gets the collection of edges.

Note that when an edge joins two endpoints belonging to two different subgraphs (or where one belongs to the root graph, and the other belongs to a subgraph), then it should be added to the common upper level graph or subgraph, not to the current graph.
Gets the collection of subgraphs.

Use a subgraph when you want to have more granular control on the layout of the nodes it contains by constraining them within a rank (see the subgraph's attribute). However, when you want the nodes to be drawn together in a bounding rectangle, that has a custom color and fill, use a cluster instead (see ). You can use either of these types to set a common style of nodes and edges within them.
Gets the collection of clusters. A cluster is a collection of nodes and edges drawn within a bounding rectangle.

summary.para: The subsections of the graph. They appear consecutively in the output DOT script, and inherit the graph attributes, and the global node and/or edge attributes of their predecessors. When overridden in any subsection, the new graph attributes and global node/edge attributes apply to the elements the section itself contains, and also to those that belong to the sections that follow it (if any).

Note that each subsection is dependent on the graph attributes and the global node and edge attributes specified by the sections that precede it (including those of the root section represented by the current element). Note also that some graph attributes cannot be overriden, and apply to the whole graph no matter in which section they are set.
As far as setting global node and/or edge attributes for a specific group of elements is concerned, may be the cleaner and preferable way to achieve the effect.

member.name: P:GiGraph.Dot.Entities.Html.Image.Attributes.IDotHtmlImageAttributes.Source
member.summary:
Specifies the image file to be displayed. Note that if the software is used as a web server, file system access to images is more restricted. See
GV_FILE_PATH
and
SERVER_NAME
.

member.name: P:GiGraph.Dot.Entities.Html.Image.Attributes.IDotHtmlImageAttributes.Scaling
member.summary: Specifies how the image will use any extra space available in its cell. If this attribute is undefined, the image inherits the image scaling of the graph. If the cell has a fixed size and the image is too large, any offending dimension will be shrunk to fit the space, the scaling being uniform in width and height if the scale is . Note that the containing cells alignment attributes override the current attribute.

member.name: P:GiGraph.Dot.Entities.Html.Image.DotHtmlImage.Source
member.summary:
Specifies the image file to be displayed. Note that if the software is used as a web server, file system access to images is more restricted. See
GV_FILE_PATH
and
SERVER_NAME
.

member.name: P:GiGraph.Dot.Entities.Html.Image.DotHtmlImage.Scaling
member.summary: Specifies how the image will use any extra space available in its cell. If this attribute is undefined, the image inherits the image scaling of the graph. If the cell has a fixed size and the image is too large, any offending dimension will be shrunk to fit the space, the scaling being uniform in width and height if the scale is . Note that the containing cells alignment attributes override the current attribute.

member.summary: Specifies horizontal placement. When an object is allocated more space than required, this value determines where the extra space is placed left and right of the object. Default: .

member.name: P:GiGraph.Dot.Entities.Html.Table.Attributes.IDotHtmlTableCellAttributes.HorizontalLineAlignment
member.summary:
Specifies the default alignment of
elements contained in the cell (). That is, if a
element has no specified explicitly, the alignment indicated by the current attribute is applied.

member.name: P:GiGraph.Dot.Entities.Html.Table.Attributes.IDotHtmlTableCellAttributes.ColumnSpan
member.summary: Specifies the number of columns spanned by the cell. The default is 1, the maximum is 65535.

member.name: P:GiGraph.Dot.Entities.Html.Table.Attributes.IDotHtmlTableCellAttributes.RowSpan

member.name: T:GiGraph.Dot.Entities.Html.Table.Attributes.IDotHtmlTableTableCellCommonAttributes
member.summary: The common attributes of an HTML table (<table>) and an HTML table cell (<td>).

member.name: P:GiGraph.Dot.Entities.Html.Table.Attributes.IDotHtmlTableTableCellCommonAttributes.Id
member.summary: Allows the user to specify a unique ID for the table.

member.name: P:GiGraph.Dot.Entities.Html.Table.Attributes.IDotHtmlTableTableCellCommonAttributes.PortName
member.summary: Attaches a port name to the object. This can be used to modify the head or tail of an edge, so that the end attaches directly to the object.

member.name: P:GiGraph.Dot.Entities.Html.Table.Attributes.IDotHtmlTableTableCellCommonAttributes.VerticalAlignment
member.summary: Specifies vertical placement. When an object is allocated more space than required, this value determines where the extra space is placed above and below the object. Default: .

member.name: P:GiGraph.Dot.Entities.Html.Table.Attributes.IDotHtmlTableTableCellCommonAttributes.BackgroundColor
member.summary: Sets the color of the background. This color can be overridden by a the same attribute in descendents. The value can be a single color () or a gradient color ().

member.name: P:GiGraph.Dot.Entities.Html.Table.Attributes.IDotHtmlTableTableCellCommonAttributes.BorderColor
member.summary: Sets the border color of the table or cell. It can be overridden by the same attribute in descendents. By default, the border color is determined by the corresponding node, edge or graph.

member.name: P:GiGraph.Dot.Entities.Html.Table.Attributes.IDotHtmlTableTableCellCommonAttributes.BorderWidth
member.summary: Specifies the width of the border around the object in points. A value of zero indicates no border. The default is 1. The maximum value is 255. If set in a table, and is not set, this value is also used for all cells in the table. It can be overridden by a corresponding attribute in a cell.

member.name: P:GiGraph.Dot.Entities.Html.Table.Attributes.IDotHtmlTableTableCellCommonAttributes.CellPadding
member.summary: Specifies the space, in points, between a cell's border and its content. The default is 2. The maximum value is 255.

member.name: P:GiGraph.Dot.Entities.Html.Table.Attributes.IDotHtmlTableTableCellCommonAttributes.CellSpacing
member.summary: Specifies the space, in points, between cells in a table and between a cell and the table's border. The default is 2. The maximum value is 127.

member.name: P:GiGraph.Dot.Entities.Html.Table.Attributes.IDotHtmlTableTableCellCommonAttributes.Borders
member.summary: Specifies which sides of a border in a cell or table should be drawn, if a border is drawn. By default, all sides are drawn. Multiple flags may be specified.

member.name: P:GiGraph.Dot.Entities.Html.Table.Attributes.IDotHtmlTableTableCellCommonAttributes.FixedSize
member.summary: Specifies whether the values given by the and attributes are enforced. False allows the object to grow so that all its contents will fit (default). True fixes the object size to its given and . Both of these attributes must be supplied.

member.name: P:GiGraph.Dot.Entities.Html.Table.Attributes.IDotHtmlTableTableCellCommonAttributes.GradientFillAngle
member.summary: Gives the angle used in a gradient fill if the is a gradient color. For the default linear gradient, this specifies the angle of a line through the center along which the colors transform. Thus, an angle of 0 will cause a left-to-right progression. For radial gradients (see ), the angle specifies the position of the center of the coloring. An angle of 0 places the center at the center of the table or cell; an non-zero angle places the fill center along that angle near the boundary.

member.name: P:GiGraph.Dot.Entities.Html.Table.Attributes.IDotHtmlTableTableCellCommonAttributes.Width
member.summary: Specifies the mininum width, in points, of the object. The width includes the contents, any spacing and the border. Unless is true, the width will be expanded to allow the contents to fit. The maximum value is 65535.

member.name: P:GiGraph.Dot.Entities.Html.Table.Attributes.IDotHtmlTableTableCellCommonAttributes.Height
member.summary: Specifies the mininum height, in points, of the object. The height includes the contents, any spacing and the border. Unless is true, the height will be expanded to allow the contents to fit. The maximum value is 65535.

member.name: P:GiGraph.Dot.Entities.Html.Table.Attributes.IDotHtmlTableTableCellCommonAttributes.Href
member.summary: Attaches a URL to the object.

member.name: P:GiGraph.Dot.Entities.Html.Table.Attributes.IDotHtmlTableTableCellCommonAttributes.Target
member.summary:
Determines which window of the browser is used for the URL if the object has one. See
W3C documentation
.

summary.para:
Gives the name of a file containing an image to be displayed inside the node. The image file must be in one of the
recognized formats
, typically JPEG, PNG, GIF, BMP, SVG or Postscript, and be able to be converted into the desired output format.

The file must contain the image size information. This is usually trivially true for the bitmap formats. For PostScript, the file must contain a line starting with %%BoundingBox: followed by four integers specifying the lower left x and y coordinates and the upper right x and y coordinates of the bounding box for the image, the coordinates being in points. An SVG image file must contain width and height attributes, typically as part of the svg element. The values for these should have the form of a floating point number, followed by optional units, e.g., width="76pt". Recognized units are in, px, pc, pt, cm and mm for inches, pixels, picas, points, centimeters and millimeters, respectively. The default unit is points.
Unlike with the shapefile attribute, the image is treated as node content rather than the entire node. In particular, an image can be contained in a node of any shape, not just a rectangle.

member.name: P:GiGraph.Dot.Entities.Nodes.Attributes.DotNodeImageAttributes.Alignment
member.summary: Controls how an image is positioned within its containing node. This only has an effect when the image is smaller than the containing node. The default is to be centered both horizontally and vertically ().

summary.para: Attribute controlling how an image fills its containing node. In general, the image is given its natural size, (compare the attribute on graph ), and the node size is made large enough to contain its image, its label, its padding, and its peripheries. Its width and height will also be at least as large as its minimum width and height. If, however, the node's is , the and attributes specify the exact size of the node.

During rendering, in the default case ( = ), the image retains its natural size. If = , the image is uniformly scaled (i.e., its aspect ratio is preserved) to fit inside the node. At least one dimension of the image will be as large as possible given the size of the node. When = , the width of the image is scaled to fill the node width. The corresponding property holds when = . When = , both the height and the width are scaled separately to fill the node.

In all cases, if a dimension of the image is larger than the corresponding dimension of the node, that dimension of the image is scaled down to fit the node. As with the case of expansion, if = , width and height are scaled uniformly.

member.name: M:GiGraph.Dot.Entities.Nodes.Attributes.DotNodeImageAttributes.Set(System.String,System.Nullable{GiGraph.Dot.Types.Alignment.DotAlignment},System.Nullable{GiGraph.Dot.Types.Images.DotImageScaling})
member.summary: Specifies image attributes.
member.param: The path to an image.
The alignment of the image.
The scaling option to apply to the image.

member.summary: Specifies image attributes.
member.param: The image attributes to set.

member.summary: Copies image attributes from the specified instance.
member.param: The instance to copy the attributes from.

summary.para: Width of node, in inches (default: 0.75, minimum: 0.01). This is taken as the initial, minimum width of the node. If is , this will be the final width of the node. Otherwise, if the node label requires more width to fit, the node's width will be increased to contain the label. Note also that, if the output format is dot, the value given to width will be the final value.

If the node shape is regular, the width and height are made identical. In this case, if either the width or the height is set explicitly, that value is used. In this case, if both the width or the height are set explicitly, the maximum of the two values is used. If neither is set explicitly, the minimum of the two default values is used.

Height of node, in inches (default: 0.5, minimum: 0.02). This is taken as the initial, minimum height of the node. If is , this will be the final height of the node. Otherwise, if the node label requires more height to fit, the node's height will be increased to contain the label. Note also that, if the output format is dot, the value given to height will be the final value.

If the node shape is regular, the width and height are made identical. In this case, if either the width or the height is set explicitly, that value is used. In this case, if both the width or the height are set explicitly, the maximum of the two values is used. If neither is set explicitly, the minimum of the two default values is used.

summary.para: Gets or sets the style of the cluster (default: unset). See the descriptions of individual values to learn which styles are applicable to this type of element.
Multiple styles can be used at once, for example: = | ;
Gets or sets the label to display on the node. It may be plain text (), HTML ( ), or a record () for a record-shaped node (when = or = ). When not specified, node identifier is used.

See also for text justification and simple formatting, for building simple tables with records, and for custom text styling and defining tables. The latter one gives the most possibilities (specifying font, size, color, style, images, etc.).

member.name: P:GiGraph.Dot.Entities.Nodes.Attributes.IDotNodeAttributes.ExternalLabel
member.summary: External label for the node. The label will be placed outside of the node but near it. This can be useful in DOT to avoid the occasional problem when the use of edge labels distorts the layout. For other layouts, this attribute can be viewed as a synonym for the attribute. These labels are added after all nodes and edges have been placed. The labels will be placed so that they do not overlap any node or label. This means it may not be possible to place all of them. To force placing all of them, use the attribute of graph .

member.name: P:GiGraph.Dot.Entities.Nodes.Attributes.IDotNodeAttributes.LabelAlignment
member.summary: Vertical placement of the label (default: ). This attribute is used only when the height of the node is larger than the height of its label.

member.name: P:GiGraph.Dot.Entities.Nodes.Attributes.IDotNodeAttributes.Tooltip
member.summary: Tooltip annotation attached to the node (svg, cmap only). If unset, Graphviz will use the attribute if defined. Note that if the label is a record specification or an HTML-like label, the resulting tooltip may be unhelpful. In this case, if tooltips will be generated, the user should set a tooltip attribute explicitly.

summary.para: Gets or sets the color to use for the node (default: ).
If is used, with no weighted colors in its parameters ( items only), and a fill style is specified for the node, a linear gradient fill is done.
If is used with weighted colors (see ), a degenerate linear gradient fill is done. This essentially does a fill using two colors, with the specifying how much of region is filled with each color.
If a fill style is specified for the node, then a radial gradient fill is done. See also the attribute for setting a gradient angle.
These fills work with any shape. For certain shapes, fill style can be set to do fills using more than 2 colors (set the fill style to or style, and use as a color list definition).

Gets or sets the color used to fill the background of the node, assuming that the fill style of the node is (default: ). If is not defined, is used. If it is not defined too, the default is used, except for of , or when the output format is MIF, which use black by default.

When is used, a gradient fill is generated. By default, this is a linear fill; applying the fill style to the node will cause a radial fill. If the second color is , the default color is used for it. See also the attribute for setting a gradient angle.

member.name: P:GiGraph.Dot.Entities.Nodes.Attributes.IDotNodeAttributes.ColorScheme
member.summary: Specifies a color scheme namespace to use. If defined, specifies the context for interpreting color names. If no color scheme is set, the standard naming is used. For example, if Brewer color scheme is used, then a color named "7", e.g. Color.FromName("7"), will be evaluated in the context of that specific color scheme. See for supported scheme names.

member.name: P:GiGraph.Dot.Entities.Nodes.Attributes.IDotNodeAttributes.GradientFillAngle
member.summary: If a gradient fill is being used, this determines the angle of the fill. For linear fills, the colors transform along a line specified by the angle and the center of the object. For radial fills, a value of zero causes the colors to transform radially from the center; for non-zero values, the colors transform from a point near the object's periphery as specified by the value. If unset, the default angle is 0.

member.name: P:GiGraph.Dot.Entities.Nodes.Attributes.IDotNodeAttributes.BorderWidth
member.summary: Specifies the width of the pen, in points, used to draw lines and curves. The value has no effect on text. Default: 1.0, minimum: 0.0.

member.name: P:GiGraph.Dot.Entities.Nodes.Attributes.IDotNodeAttributes.Shape
member.summary: Gets or sets the shape of the node (default: ).

member.name: P:GiGraph.Dot.Entities.Nodes.Attributes.IDotNodeAttributes.Padding
member.summary: Specifies space left around the node's label. By default, the value is (0.11, 0.055).

member.name: P:GiGraph.Dot.Entities.Nodes.Attributes.IDotNodeAttributes.Comment
member.summary: Comments are inserted into output. Device-dependent.

member.name: P:GiGraph.Dot.Entities.Nodes.Attributes.IDotNodeAttributes.EdgeOrderingMode
member.summary: Determines how inedges and outedges, that is, edges with the node as their head or tail node respectively, are ordered (dot only). If defined on a graph or subgraph, the value is applied to all nodes in the graph or subgraph. Note that the corresponding graph attribute takes precedence over the node attribute.

member.name: P:GiGraph.Dot.Entities.Nodes.Attributes.IDotNodeAttributes.GroupName
member.summary: The name of the group the node belongs to (dot only). If the endpoints of an edge belong to the same group (have the same group name assigned), parameters are set to avoid crossings and keep the edges straight (dot only).

member.name: P:GiGraph.Dot.Entities.Nodes.Attributes.IDotNodeAttributes.SortIndex
member.summary: Gets or sets the sorting index of the node (default: 0). If of graph indicates an array packing, this attribute specifies an insertion order among the components, with smaller values inserted first.

summary.para: Specifies whether the node should be used as the center of the layout and the root of the generated spanning tree (default: false; circo, twopi only).

In twopi, root will actually be the central node. In circo, the block containing the node will be central in the drawing of its connected component. If not defined, twopi will pick a most central node, and circo will pick a random node.
If the attribute on the graph is defined as the empty string, twopi will reset it to name of the node picked as the root node.
For twopi, it is possible to have multiple roots, presumably one for each component. If more than one node in a component is marked as the root, twopi will pick one.
Allows the graph author to provide an identifier for graph objects which is to be included in the output (svg, postscript, map only).
Normal , , substitutions can be applied (see ). Note, however, that does not provide a unique ID for multi-edges.

If provided, it is the responsibility of the provider to keep ID values unique for its intended downstream use. If no ID attribute is provided, then a unique internal ID is used. However, this value is unpredictable by the graph writer.

If the graph provides an ID attribute, this will be used as a prefix for internally generated attributes. By making internally-used attributes distinct, the user can include multiple image maps in the same document.

member.summary: Determines how inedges and outedges, that is, edges with the node as their head or tail node respectively, are ordered (dot only). If defined on a graph or subgraph, the value is applied to all nodes in the graph or subgraph. Note that the corresponding graph attribute takes precedence over the node attribute.

member.name: P:GiGraph.Dot.Entities.Nodes.Collections.DotNodeCollection.GroupName
member.summary: The name of the group the node belongs to (dot only). If the endpoints of an edge belong to the same group (have the same group name assigned), parameters are set to avoid crossings and keep the edges straight (dot only).

member.name: P:GiGraph.Dot.Entities.Nodes.Collections.DotNodeCollection.SortIndex
member.summary: Gets or sets the sorting index of the node (default: 0). If of graph indicates an array packing, this attribute specifies an insertion order among the components, with smaller values inserted first.

summary.para: Specifies whether the node should be used as the center of the layout and the root of the generated spanning tree (default: false; circo, twopi only).

In twopi, root will actually be the central node. In circo, the block containing the node will be central in the drawing of its connected component. If not defined, twopi will pick a most central node, and circo will pick a random node.
If the attribute on the graph is defined as the empty string, twopi will reset it to name of the node picked as the root node.
For twopi, it is possible to have multiple roots, presumably one for each component. If more than one node in a component is marked as the root, twopi will pick one.
Allows the graph author to provide an identifier for graph objects which is to be included in the output (svg, postscript, map only).
Normal , , substitutions can be applied (see ). Note, however, that does not provide a unique ID for multi-edges.

If provided, it is the responsibility of the provider to keep ID values unique for its intended downstream use. If no ID attribute is provided, then a unique internal ID is used. However, this value is unpredictable by the graph writer.

If the graph provides an ID attribute, this will be used as a prefix for internally generated attributes. By making internally-used attributes distinct, the user can include multiple image maps in the same document.
